Description: See RDM standard for RDM devices.  Performs a discovery and returns an ordered list of nodes on XMX devices
See RDM standard
See RDM standard
See RDM standard
See RDM standard
See RDM standard

See RDM Standard
Returns the following values:
- Protocol version (top 2 bytes) - fixed value of 0x0100 for RDM or 0x8000 for XMX protocol and CKDMX gen2
- Device Model ID (next 2 bytes) [from opcode 0x8070]
- Product Category (next 2 bytes) [from opcode 0x8070]
- SFT Version (next 4 bytes) [from opcode 0x80C0]
- Channel count (next 2 bytes) [returns same value as opcode 0x860F, fixed at 0x0000 for PDS]
- Device personality (next 2 bytes) - temporary fixed value of 0x0000 for PDS and 0xFFFF for node
- Device start address (next 2 bytes) [from opcode 0x00F0, fixed at 0xFFFF for PDS]
- Sub-device count (next 2 bytes) - Devices without subdevices report a fixed value of 0x0000
- Sensor count (bottom byte) - Devices which do not suport opcode 0x0200 return a fixed value of 0x00
See RDM Standard
See RDM Standard
See RDM Standard
See RDM Standard
See RDM Standard
See RDM Standard

See RDM Standard.
Returns if the device is currently in the factory default state.  A device is in the factory default state if no settings have been modified since the device was restored to factory defaults.  If a user manually sets device settings to the same values defined in factory defaults, the fixture is not set to factory defaults.

See RDM Standard.
When set, restores the device to factory defaults.  Factory defaults are defined as the firmware defaults for a device that is unlocked or lacks a separate manufacturing defaults database, and the contents of the manufacturing defaults database for a device that has such a database and is locked.

See RDM standard.
Returns a human-readable, ASCII-encoded, software version string in the following format:
SFT-012345-67 A:89 B:12
where A: is the application software version and B: is the bootloader version
The string returned is the same as the software version string returned by KiNET discovery
Returns same value as PID 0x00C0
See RDM Standard
See RDM Standard
See RDM standard

Returns the byte index of the light data packet that corresponds to the first fixture LED channel.  For compatibility with DMX addresses, an index of 1 corresponds to the first byte in the light data packet.  As an example, a fixture with a node light index of 0x04 would ignore the first 3 bytes of light data, and start reading light data beginning with the 4th byte.  A node light index of 0 is undefined.
See sensor table for list of sensors and descriptions.  "Normal" minima and maxima are not defined; -32768 and 32767 should be returned for the normal minium and normal maximum respectively
See RDM standard for format, and see sensor list below.  "Recorded value" is not supported

See RDM Standard
The following Dimming curves are defined:
0x01: Linear
0x02: CK Normal
0x03: CK Tungsten
See RDM Standard
See RDM Standard
See RDM Standard
See RDM sandard
This parameter is used to set the number of hours of operation the device has been in use. Only allow to set to 0x00000000 before manufacturing lock enabling.

Returns the state of device identify for the device.  The following states are defined: 
- 0x00 (identify off)
- 0x01 (identify active)
The behavior of "device identify" for PDS units is still being defined, but will only involve indicatiors local to the PDS and will not involve attached nodes.
Sets the state of device identify for the PDS
Resets the target device.

Gets/sets the state of the output power switching.  The following states are defined:
- 0xFF: Output power enabled.  [POWER_STATE_NORMAL]
- 0x02: Output power disabled [POWER_STATE_STANDBY]
This is a partial duplication of the functionality available via opcode 0x9040
This is a partial duplication of the functionality available via opcode 0x9040
Returns the mode  the node passthrough commands.   0x00: the node passthrough the commands; 0x01: the node doesn't passthrough the commands
Gets the method to be used for node discovery.   0x00 is combined discovery, 0x01 is address line discovery ("fast discovery"), 0x02 is robust discovery
Returns number of sub-devices. On GrazeElite, it is the # of DLEs / fixture, or # of pixels / DLE

Payload includes:
- Index for a sub-device (16-bit, 0 - PCC, n(n > 0) - the nth DLE)
- PID (16-bit, PID sent to the target sub-device, exclude 8012)
- Data (optional for the PID needs parameter for GET command, for example 9FEE)
Response is the response payload of the PID

Payload includes:
- Index for a sub-device (16-bit, 0 - PCC, n(n > 0) - the nth DLE)
- PID (16-bit, PID sent to the target sub-device, exclude 8012)
- Payload of SET PID command to the target sub-device

Payload indicates the port to return statistics for.  This value is zero-indexed.  For devices that only have a single port, the port indication may be ignored.
Response includes:
- Total transmitted packets (top 4 bytes)
- Total received packets (next 4 bytes)
- Received packet length errors (next 4 bytes)
- Received  packet CRC errors (next 4 bytes)
- UART receive errors (next 4 bytes)
- Processed packets with invalid data (next 4 bytes)
- Received packets intended for device (bottom 4 bytes)
Packet and error statistics are counted from the most recent clear command or device reset.  Packet errors generated by responses to ranged commands are excluded from the statistics.
Payload indicates the port to clear statistics for.  This value is zero-indexed.  For devices that only have a single port, the port indication may be ignored.

Purpose: Get list of fixtures with errors
Description: Returns a packed list of fixture SNs with device failure codes reported.

Purpose: Clear list of fixtures with errors

Description: Returns the device failure code.  A list of failure codes can be found in the "Error codes"  sheet within this document.  This value is cleared on device reset or upon a change in error condition.

Places device into diagnostic mode, runs device self test, and returns device failure code upon completion of self test.  For devices where all parameters are monitored without entering a diagnostic mode, the functionality of this command is the same as "Get device failure code"

Returns a set of CRC-16 values for the various device databases.  The polynomial used for the CRC calculations is x^16+x^12+x^5+1 (CRC-16 CCITT).
For databases that are not present, 0x0000 should be returned as the CRC.
- Top 2 bytes are reserved for future use - 0x0000 should be returned in this slot
- Next 2 bytes are MFG Data CRC
- Next 2 bytes are MBR CRC
- Low 2 bytes are Settings CRC
Returns a count of how many opcodes are supported on the device

Returns a list of opcodes that can be queried or set on the device.  Format is a packed list of 16x 16-bit opcodes.  Command class is not returned by this command.  This opcode requires a 16-bit data offset as part of the query.  The 0x0000 opcode is not returned by this command, and is used to pad responses to 256 bits.

Return raw data in the target backup memory bank.
The query command requires 3 bytes arguments:
- Memory offset of the target node memory bank used for backup (16-bit offset in number of bytes, as well as the index of the first byte in memory bank to query) [top 2 bytes]
- Data size to query (8-bit for number of bytes to query, shouldn't be larger than 32) [bottom 1 byte]
Ex, 0x0010 08 is querying 8 bytes from byte 0x10 in the memory bank

Backup data at the designated offset in the backup memory, or SET an opcode values
Payload is variable length between 4 and 35 bytes as follows:
- Top 2 bytes: Offset (16-bit offset for the data to store on the target DLE) / PID to set data to the target node
- Next highest byte: PID type (8-bit, 1 = the above is a 16-bit offset, 2 = the above is a PID)
- Bottom bytes: Payload of data to store or set, 1-32 bytes
Return status of data restore process: 0 = idle; 1 = restore is in progress

Payload includes:
- Source device index (16-bit, 0 is PCC, 1 or above is DLE) [top 2 bytes]
- Destination device index (16-bit, 0 is PCC, 1 or above is DLE) [bottom 2 bytes]
When both source index and destination index are 0, force to backup from PCC to all DLEs
Returns the device serial number, a globally unique identifier.

Returns the device type.  The device type is a 32-bit field constructed from the following 2 16-bit properties:
- Device Model ID (high 16 bits)
- Product Category (low 16 bits)
Returns hardware board ID
Returns product top-level SKU, maximum of 32 characters  Format is ASCII, with characters padded to 8 bits with a 0 as the MSB.
Sets product top-level SKU, maximum of 32 characters  Format is ASCII, with characters  padded to 8 bits with a 0 as the MSB.  The special string 0xFF may be used to clear this field

Returns the date of manufacture.  This is a 7 byte field of the format [year:year:month:day:hour:minute:second]
Year is a 16-bit value
Returns the Optibin bin code

Returns the device version number.  This is comprised of:.
- SFT number (16-bit) - top 2 bytes
- SFT variant (8-bit)
- SFT build version (8-bit) - bottom byte

Returns information on the multi-node assembly.  Information contained in this opcode is as follows:
- Number of nodes in assembly (top 2 bytes)
- Node number in assembly (next 2 bytes).  A value of 0xFFFF in this field is used for nodes where the location is unknown
- 12 ASCII character top-level assembly serial number (bottom 12 bytes).  All ASCII characters are padded to 8-bits with a 0 as the MSB

Returns the number of controllable pixels physically present in the device, independent of any pixel resolution settings.  Does not perform a discovery; discovery can be performed by quering PID 0x0011 or 0x0010
Used to manually override the discovered pixel count

GET payload is the 16-bit sensor ID
Response includes:
- Sensor ID (8 bit unsigned) [MSB]
- Mean Value (16 bit signed)
- Timestamp of minimum (32 bit unsigned)
- Timestamp of maximum (32 bit unsigned)
- Rolling 1 minute min-max delta (16 bit signed) [LSB]

Queries the mode the device is in.  The following values are permitted responses:
0x00: Operation Mode
0x02: Admin Mode
0x03: Bootloader Mode
0x04: Recovery Mode
0x05: Factory Test Mode

Returns device temperature in °C
CPU temperature and temperature for each LED string present required
If LED temperature sensors are not present, the value from an alternate temperature sensor with good correlation to the LED string temperature may be returned as the LED string temperature
PCC: 1 byte for PCC CPU temp
DLE: 3 bytes for:
- CPU temp.
- Sensor 1 temp. 
- Sensor 2 temp.
GrazeElite: Returns signed bytes as device temperatures in °C:
- Highest temperature of all following values
- PCC CPU temp.
- DLE 1 CPU temp.
- DLE 1 sensor 1 temp. for channel 1 - 5
- DLE 1 sensor 2 temp. for channel 6 - 10
- [temps for other DLEs]

Returns the following values:
- Session CPU max temperature (top 8 bits, signed)
- Timestamp of session CPU max temperature (32 bit)
- Session CPU minimum temperature (8 bit, signed)
- Timestamp of session CPU minimum temperature (32 bits)
-  Mean CPU temperature in session (bottom 8 bits, signed)

Returns the following values:
- Lifetime max CPU temperature (MSB, signed)
- Timestamp of lifetime max CPU temperature (4 bytes)
These values persist through resets and power events.

Returns the following values:
- Fixture currently in thermal shutdown (0x00: normal operation, 0x01: thermal shutdown)
- Count thermal shutdown events in session (8 bit)

Returns the following values:
- Count all time thermal shutdown events (16 bit)
- Timestamp of most recent thermal shutdown event (32 bit)
These values persist through resets and power events.

Returns which LED strings are open.  Bit 0 is LED string 0, Bit 1 is LED string 1, etc.  High bits indicate string open, low bits indicate string functional.  0x00 is all strings good, 0x01 is string 0 open, other strings functional, etc.

Purpose: Get LED string open status change timestamp
Description: Returns timestamp of last change in LED string open status

Returns which LED strings have a shorted LED.  Bit 0 is LED string 0, Bit 1 is LED string 1, etc.  High bits indicate string has shorted LED, low bits indicate string functional.  0x00 is all strings good, 0x01 is string 0 shorted LED, other strings functional, etc.

Purpose: Get LED string shorted status change timestamp
Description: Returns timestamp of last change in LED string shorted status

Purpose: Get LED string stuck on status
Description: Returns which LED strings are stuck on.  Bit 0 is LED string 0, Bit 1 is LED string 1, etc.  High bits indicate string stuck on, low bits indicate string functional.  0x00 is all strings good, 0x01 is string 0 stuck on, other strings functional, etc.

Purpose: Get LED string stuck status change timestamp
Description: Returns timestamp of last change in LED string stuck status
Returns node input voltage in millivolts.

Purpose: Get node input voltage session statistics
Description:
Returns the following values:
- Input voltage maximum in session (high 16 bits)
- Input voltage minimum in session (16 bits)
- Input voltage mean in session (16 bits)
- Input voltage 1 minute rolling min-max delta (bottom 16 bits)

Returns internal rail voltage in millivolts
DLE:
- High rail voltage in mV (high 16-bit)
- Low rail voltage in mV (middle 16-bit)
- Driver voltage in mV (bottom 16-bit)

Purpose: Get Internal rail voltage session statistics
Description:
Returns the following values:
- internal rail voltage maximum in session (high 16 bits)
- internal rail voltage minimum in session (16 bits)
- internal rail voltage mean in session (16 bits)
- internal rail voltage 1 minute rolling min-max delta (bottom 16 bits)
DLE:
- High rail voltage maximum in session (high 16 bits)
- High rail voltage minimum in session (16 bits)
- High rail voltage mean in session (16 bits)
- High rail voltage 1 minute rolling min-max delta (16 bits)
- Low rail voltage maximum in session (16 bits)
- Low rail voltage minimum in session (16 bits)
- Low rail voltage mean in session (16 bits)
- Low rail voltage 1 minute rolling min-max delta (bottom 16 bits)

Returns the following 8-bit values:
 - Number of times Mdefault DB (MD)  is loaded in Application DB (ADB)
 - Number of times Firmware Default is loaded into ADB
 - Number of times crc failed during DB load/read
 - Number of times DB write failed.
Resets the database statistics

Returns the 5 most recent database read CRCs and associated timestamps, as follows:
 - Most recent database read CRC (16-bits)
 - Most recent  database read timestamp (32-bits)
 - Database CRC and timestamp for next most recent read
 - Database CRC and timestamp for third most recent read
 - Database CRC and timestamp for fourth most recent read
 - Database CRC and timestamp for fifth most recent read
Returns operating time in seconds.  This value persists through resets and power events.  This value is used for timestamps.
Resets the device operating time and clears all timestamps
Returns timestamp of most recent power-on event
Returns timestamp of start of most recent session

Includes
- Total resets (high 4 bytes)
- Total watchdog events (low 4 bytes)
These values persist through resets and power events.
Returns count of all-time power-on events

Runs a maufacturing test.  Payload is as follows
 - First byte is the manufacturing test category
 - Second byte is the specific manufacturing test
 - Third and fourth bytes are the device model ID
 - Subsequent bytes are the test parameters

Returns the number of bits used by each LED channel.  The following options are defined:
- 0x00: high-resolution (16-bit) channel control
- 0x01: standard-resolution (typically 8-bit) channel control

Returns the dimming curve used by the node.  The following options are defined:
- 0x00: Linear curve
- 0x01: Quadratic (CK Normal) curve
- 0x02: Tungsten curve

Returns the configuraton of deep dimming algorithm DSM (Delta-Sigma-Modulation). The payload includes:
- Rev. number (8-bit, 1 - DSM1, 2 - DSM2) [top 1 byte]
- Min. pulse width in clock cycles (16-bit) [next 2 bytes]
- LED driver latency in clock cycles (16-bit) [bottom 2 bytes]
- Max. pulse width in clock cycles (optional, 16-bit. The above 2 parameters shall be set smaller than this value)
Returns the fade speed used by the node
Returns strobe enable status and light frame interval in milliseconds

Returns the Chromasync input mode.  The following values are defined:
- 0x00: n-channel input & n-channel output (Chromasync off)
- 0x01: 3-channel input & 3-channel output (Chromasync off)
- 0x02: 3-channel input & n-channel output (Chromasync on)
- 0x03: n-channel input and & n-channel output (Chromasync on)
- 0x04: 3-channel input and 3-channel output (Chromasync on)
- 0x05: 3-channel input & n-channel output (SimpleSync on)
- 0x06: Intensity only mode (Chromasync off)
- 0x07: xyY color control mode (Chromasync on)
- 0x08: 3-channel input & n-channel output (SimpleSync Low Power on)
- 0x09: 4-channel spectrum manipulation
- 0x0A: 2-channel white input & n-channel output (iW mode)
- 0x0B: 4-channel input & n-channel output (RGBW mode)

Not all modes are required to be implemented

Returns the order of pixels within the fixture.
 - 0x00: First pixel is closest to the input connector
 - 0xFF: First pixel is furthest from the input connector

Returns the number of LED pixels that 1 pixel data in light data frame are used for. The following values are defined:
- 0: Use 1-pixel data for all LED pixels of the luminaire
- n (n > 0): 1-pixel data from the light data frame will be applied on n LED pixels
Returns the number of logical control channels used by the device

Returns the values the LED channels go to when the node is initialized with no data stream present.  LED channel values are 16 bit resolution, and are sequential from channel 0 to channel 4.  Startup values are handled in the same way as light data received via a light data packet, and are affected by Chromasync, dimming curve, and channel map.  Unused channels are ignored at the node.

Returns the values the LED channels go to when the node is initialized with no data stream present.  LED channel values are 16 bit resolution, and are sequential from channel 0 to channel 4.  Startup values are handled in the same way as light data received via a light data packet, and are affected by Chromasync, dimming curve, and channel map.  Unused channels are ignored at the node.

Returns the values the LED channels go to when the node is initialized with no data stream present.  LED channel values are 16 bit resolution, and are sequential from channel 0 to channel 4.  Startup values are handled in the same way as light data received via a light data packet, and are affected by Chromasync, dimming curve, and channel map.  Unused channels are ignored at the node.

Returns the values the LED channels go to when the node is initialized with no data stream present.  LED channel values are 16 bit resolution, and are sequential from channel 0 to channel 4.  Startup values are handled in the same way as light data received via a light data packet, and are affected by Chromasync, dimming curve, and channel map.  Unused channels are ignored at the node.

Returns the values the LED channels go to when the node is initialized with no data stream present.  LED channel values are 16 bit resolution, and are sequential from channel 0 to channel 4.  Startup values are handled in the same way as light data received via a light data packet, and are affected by Chromasync, dimming curve, and channel map.  Unused channels are ignored at the node.

7 Ports of the following: 
- 2 bytes Port Status Register 
- 2 bytes Port Control Register
- 2 bytes Port Packet Rx Count
- 2 bytes Port Packet Tx Count
- 2 bytes Port Packet Discard Count
- 2 bytes Port Packet Filtered Count
To be defined based on available statistics from PoE controller chip

Returns the sACN universe for a port on the device.  The port number to query is a single byte payload sent as part of the GET request.  The response takes the form
 - Top 2 bytes are the port number
 - Bottom 2 bytes are the sACN universe
A GET with no port number in the payload should be responded with the values for port 1, but may optionally respond with port number 0xFFFF if all ports are set to the same universe.  Port number 0x0000 is not used.

Sets the sACN universe for a port on the device.  The top 2 bytes denote the port, and the bottom 2 bytes denote the sACN universe.  The special port number 0xFFFF is used to set all ports on the device to the same sACN universe.

Returns the status of the device lock.  The following states are defined: 
- 0x4F50454E: open ("OPEN") - The protected settings are allowed to change
- 0x4C4F434B: Locked ("LOCK")
- 0xB3B0BCB4: Unlocked (~"LOCK") - All settings in this state are factory defaults and allowed to change

Payload: Magic value of 0x4C4F434B (ASCII for LOCK), or 32-bit temporary open Key
Description:
Locks factory settings on device.  CANNOT BE CLEARED ONCE SET.
Temporary open key is  a 32-bit CRC: low 16-bit is computed with CRC16-CCITT polynomial 0x1021 initial 0 from 4-byte SN; and high 16-bit is computed from low 16-bit CRC as initial, plus bytes 0x4F, 0x50, 0x45, 0x4E (“OPEN”), and mfg ID 0x43, 0x4B

Returns the state of the address line inputs and outputs on the device.  This takes the form of an 8-bit bitmask: bit 0 corresponds to the input address line, and bits 1 through 7 correspond to output address lines on ports 0-6 respectively.  Address line asserted is denoted by a logical 1, and address line not asserted is denoted by a logical 0

Sets the state of the address line inputs and outputs on the device.  This takes the form of an 8-bit bitmask: bit 0 corresponds to the input address line, and bits 1 through 7 correspond to output address lines on ports 0-6 respectively. Bit 0 is ignored.  Address line asserted is denoted by a logical 1, and address line not asserted is denoted by a logical 0

Returns the mode for the 0-10V input.  Defined modes are:
0x00: Port disabled
0x01: Input scales incoming light data
0x02: Input is passed to upstream control system

The response payload takes the form of a 132 byte field, corresponding to the 33 4-byte KTOKENs used for setting input routing.  The MSB corresponds to KTOKEN 1100, with subsequent bytes corresponding to KTOKENs 1101:1132.  Further details will be documented in a separate document outlining the protocol mapping scheme.

Sets the current status of the light data buffers.  This is functionally equivalent to a light data packet containing light data addressed to the fixture.  This takes the form of 5 16-bit values, one per LED channel.
Sets or Gets state. 0x00=not active, 0x01=active.
Sets or Gets state. 0x00=not active, 0x01=active.

Gets or sets the parameters for the internal fixed color effect.  Format is as follows
- Format (1 byte)
- Payload (variable up to 15 bytes, depends on format)
The following formats are defined:
- 0x00: Raw buffer, max of 15 bytes
- 0x01: HSV (16-bit hue [range 0:1535], 8-bit saturation, 8-bit intensity)
- 0x02: xyY normal resolution (12-bit x, 12-bit y, 8-bit intensity; x and y are packed into 3 bytes)
- 0x03: xyY high resolution (16-bit x, 16-bit Y, 16-bit intensity)

Gets or sets PDS power mode.  Top byte is mode, next 2 bytes are timeout in seconds.   Attempts to enable power when a hardware fault is detected are respnded with NACK:hardware fault.  Errors are reported via the fault code. Defined modes are:

0x01: Output power disabled.  $timeout is ignored
0x10: Output off when no data received for $timeout seconds
0x20: Output off when no data or black data received for $timeout seconds
0xFF: Output power enabled.  $timeout is ignored
A timeout of 0 is not allowed

Gets current state of PDS output power.  Top three bytes are duplicated from PID 0x9040: the top byte is the power mode, and the next 2 bytes are the timeout in seconds.  The next byte is the current output state.  The last 2 bytes are the elapsed time into the timeout (e.g. time with black data for mode 0x20), in seconds.  For modes that ignore the timeout, 0x0000 should be returned as elapsed time.  For timeouts based on receipt of data, the elapsed time is always 0x0000 because the query command counts as incoming data.

The following modes are defined:
0x01: Output power disabled.  $timeout is ignored
0x10: Output off when no data received for $timeout seconds
0x20: Output off when no data or black data received for $timeout seconds
0xFF: Output power enabled.  $timeout is ignored

The following states are defined:
0x02: Output power disabled by user
0x82: Output power disabled by timeout
0xFF: Output power enabled

Gets or sets the usage of CKDMX integrity packets.  The following modes are defined
0x00: Integrity packets not sent
0x01: Integrity packets sent opportunistically (packets will be sent if timing allows)
0x0F: Integrity packets always sent (may drop light data)

Places a node into bootloader mode in preparation for a firmware update. 
Support broadcast on passthrough devices
Returns the operating gamut used by Chromasync.  This takes the form of 5 sets of 16-bit tristimulus values (one set per LED channel)

Return the inner gamut used by Chromasync 3.  This takes the form of 5 16-bit ratios corresponding to the 5 sets of tristimulus values in the Chromasync operating gamut.  The corners of the inner gamut are defined as the distance along a unit line extending from the center of the Chromasync operating gamut to each corner of the Chromasync operating gamut
Returns the difference, in °C, between 2 temperature readings required for temperature compensation to recalculate the natural gamut
Returns the temperature compensation slopes.  This takes the form of one 16-bit slope per tristimulus value per channel (a total of 15 scale factors)
Returns the scale factor applied to the temperature compensation slopes.
Returns the Chromasync temperature compensation slope offset

Returns the natural (measured) gamut of the fixture.  This takes the form of 5 sets of 16-bit tristimulus values (one set per LED channel). An optional byte as the payload of GET command is the index of the target pixel: if no it, the target pixel index is 0 as default
An optional byte appended to the 5 sets of 16-bit tristimulus values is the index of the target pixel: if no it, the target pixel index is 0 as default

Returns node temperature per channel at the time of Chromasync measurements, in °C
An optional byte as the payload of GET command is the index of the target pixel: if no it, the target pixel index is 0 as default
An optional byte appended to the 5 byte values is the index of the target pixel: if no it, the target pixel index is 0 as default

Purpose: Get CRI targeting and limiting ratios
Description:
For CS 2.0 devices:  Returns the CRI targeting ratios used by Chromasync CRI targeting.  Enabled/Disabled using 9C4A.
For CS 3.0 devices:  Returns the ratios used to limit channel usage - may be used to cap usage of specific color channels in Flakfizer color point calculations.  Always enabled when using Chromasync input mode; disable by providing no scaling (all FF) for 9C4A.
This takes the form of one 8-bit scale factor per channel

Purpose: Set CRI targeting and limiting ratios

Description:
For CS 2.0 Devices:  Returns the CRI targeting state (use/don't use 9C40).  
For CS 3.0 Devices:  (AKA CRI Optimization) Returns the spectral adjustment state  (use/don't use 9C60)
The following values are defined:
- 0x00: CRI Targeting/CRI Optimization/Spectral Adjustment Disabled
- 0x01: CRI Targeting/CRI Optimization/Spectral Adjustment Enabled

Returns the Chromasync saturation blending mode.  The following modes are defined:
- 0x00: Saturation Blending Disabled
- 0x01: Saturation Blending Enabled
For CS 3.0 Devices only - Enabled via 9C4A - Returns 1 byte signed scale factor applied to the following 16-bit coefficients, and 3 sets of 5 16-bit signed CRI coeffient values.

Purpose: Get Temperature Compensation Slope Coefficients a
Description: Returns 3 sets of 5 16-bit signed values & 1 byte signed scale factor for values of "a" in temperature compensation equation Y = Y0 * ( 1 + (I – I0) * Mi ) * ( 1 + (T – T0) * Mt ), where Mi = ai * T0 + bi, Mt = c * I^2 + b * I + a.

Purpose: Set Temperature Compensation Slope Coefficients a
Description: Set 3 sets of 5 16-bit signed values & 1 byte signed scale factor for values of "a" in temperature compensation equation Y = Y0 * ( 1 + (I – I0) * Mi ) * ( 1 + (T – T0) * Mt ), where Mi = ai * T0 + bi, Mt = c * I^2 + b * I + a.

Purpose: Get Temperature Compensation Slope Coefficients b
Description: Returns 3 sets of 5 16-bit signed values & 1 byte signed scale factor for values of "b" in temperature compensation equation Y = Y0 * ( 1 + (I – I0) * Mi ) * ( 1 + (T – T0) * Mt ), where Mi = ai * T0 + bi, Mt = c * I^2 + b * I + a.

Purpose: Set Temperature Compensation Slope Coefficients b
Description: Set 3 sets of 5 16-bit signed values & 1 byte signed scale factor for values of "b" in temperature compensation equation Y = Y0 * ( 1 + (I – I0) * Mi ) * ( 1 + (T – T0) * Mt ), where Mi = ai * T0 + bi, Mt = c * I^2 + b * I + a.

Purpose: Get Temperature Compensation Slope Coefficients c
Description: Returns 3 sets of 5 16-bit signed values & 1 byte signed scale factor for values of "c" in temperature compensation equation Y = Y0 * ( 1 + (I – I0) * Mi ) * ( 1 + (T – T0) * Mt ), where Mi = ai * T0 + bi, Mt = c * I^2 + b * I + a.

Purpose: Set Temperature Compensation Slope Coefficients c
Description: Set 3 sets of 5 16-bit signed values & 1 byte signed scale factor for values of "c" in temperature compensation equation Y = Y0 * ( 1 + (I – I0) * Mi ) * ( 1 + (T – T0) * Mt ), where Mi = ai * T0 + bi, Mt = c * I^2 + b * I + a.

Returns 3 sets of 5 16-bit signed values & 1 byte signed scale factor for values of "ai" in temperature compensation equation Y = Y0 * ( 1 + (I – I0) * Mi ) * ( 1 + (T – T0) * Mt ), where Mi = ai * T0 + bi, Mt = c * I^2 + b * I + a.

Set 3 sets of 5 16-bit signed values & 1 byte signed scale factor for values of "ai" in temperature compensation equation Y = Y0 * ( 1 + (I – I0) * Mi ) * ( 1 + (T – T0) * Mt ), where Mi = ai * T0 + bi, Mt = c * I^2 + b * I + a.

Returns 3 sets of 5 16-bit signed values & 1 byte signed scale factor for values of "bi" in temperature compensation equation Y = Y0 * ( 1 + (I – I0) * Mi ) * ( 1 + (T – T0) * Mt ), where Mi = ai * T0 + bi, Mt = c * I^2 + b * I + a.

Set 3 sets of 5 16-bit signed values & 1 byte signed scale factor for values of "bi" in temperature compensation equation Y = Y0 * ( 1 + (I – I0) * Mi ) * ( 1 + (T – T0) * Mt ), where Mi = ai * T0 + bi, Mt = c * I^2 + b * I + a.
Return 16-bit unsigned value of "I0" in temperature compensation equation Y = Y0 * ( 1 + (I – I0) * Mi ) * ( 1 + (T – T0) * Mt ), where Mi = ai * T0 + bi, Mt = c * I^2 + b * I + a.
Set 16-bit unsigned value of "I0" in temperature compensation equation Y = Y0 * ( 1 + (I – I0) * Mi ) * ( 1 + (T – T0) * Mt ), where Mi = ai * T0 + bi, Mt = c * I^2 + b * I + a.

Returns the RGB values that equal the white point used by the SimpleSync algorithm as follows:
 - Red ratio (8 bits)
 - Green ratio (8 bits)
 - Blue ratio (8 bits)
These RGB values use a linear dimming curve

Returns the 16-bit ratio of warm to cool used to create a single virtual white channel from a pair of white CCTs, as follows:
WarmWhite Lightdata = (WhiteRatio/65535) * WhiteLightData 
CoolWhite Lightdata = ((65535- WhiteRatio)/65535) * WhiteLightData

Returns the operating mode for Dynamic Beam operation.  The following modes are defined:
0x00: Direct control of each optical zone
0x01: Static beam angle set by PID 0x9D01
0x02: Dynamic beam angle set by light data input

Returns the static dynamic beam angle used when PID 0x9D00 is set to 0x01.  Angle is defined as a linear interpolation between the narrowest and widest angles the hardwareis capable of, with 0x00 corresponding to the narrowest angle and 0xFF corresponding to the widest angle.

Returns the mapping of inputs to LED channels.  The channel map consists of 5 bytes, each corresponding to one LED channel.  Each byte of the map provides the offset from the light index for that channel.  If the LED channel is not present, this is represented by 0xFF for the light offset.  A 4 channel fixture with the channels mapped 1:1 to the input channels would have the channel map 0x00010203FF
Returns the mix of LEDs for the fixture.  A list of defined values can be found in the "LED Chemistries" sheet within this document

Returns the scale factors for the LED channels.  The scale factor is an 8 bit value for each LED channel, and is used to reduce the output of one or more channels.  LED channel output is scaled according to the following equation: output = input * (scaler / 255)

Returns the scale factors for the LED channels.  The scale factor is an 8 bit value for each LED channel, and is used to reduce the output of one or more channels.  LED channel output is scaled according to the following equation: output = input * (scaler / 255)

Returns the scale factors for the LED channels.  The scale factor is an 8 bit value for each LED channel, and is used to reduce the output of one or more channels.  LED channel output is scaled according to the following equation: output = input * (scaler / 255)

Returns the scale factors for the LED channels.  The scale factor is an 8 bit value for each LED channel, and is used to reduce the output of one or more channels.  LED channel output is scaled according to the following equation: output = input * (scaler / 255)

Returns the scale factors for the LED channels.  The scale factor is an 8 bit value for each LED channel, and is used to reduce the output of one or more channels.  LED channel output is scaled according to the following equation: output = input * (scaler / 255)
Returns the temperature, in °C, at which the fixture enters thermal shutdown
Returns the temperature, in °C, at which the fixture exits thermal shutdown

Includes:
- 16-bit current for 5 channels (mA) (top 10 bytes)
- 16-bit voltage for 5 channels (decivolts) (next 10 bytes)
- 16-bit total LED power limit (centiwatts) (bottom 2 bytes)
Currents are not configurable, only voltages and total LED power limit are configurable
Return 16-bit current value in mA
Return 16-bit values A1, B1, which are coefficients to compute DAC input value from from reference string current
Return 10 bytes as 10 channel current scalers in percentage of the reference string current

Includes:
- PSU VCTRL duty cycle (16-bit percentage) (top 2 bytes)
The following data are options
- PSU nominal frequency (16-bit kHz) (next 2 bytes)
- PSU nominal frequency variation (16-bit / 0.1% steps) (next 2 bytes)
- PSU dithering frequency (16-bit / 100Hz steps) (next 2 bytes)
- PSU dithering range (16-bit / 100Hz steps) (bottom 2 bytes)

Includes:
- 8-bit PM timing scaler (10/255 minutes; 0=disable) [MSB]
- PM minimum wattage (16-bit centiwatts) [Bottom 2 bytes]

Includes:
- Thermal Management active threshold temperature (signed 8-bit in °C, start to dim output when temperature is above it) [top byte]
- The max percentage to dim the output by (8-bit percentage, 0 disable thermal management) [next 1 byte]
- Dim rate (8-bit percentage / minute) [bottom 1 byte]

MSB is PWM Frequency, valid values are in {00,01,02,03,04,05,07}
LSB is a packed value containing the following settings:
 - PWM phase shift enable (top bit)
 - Iout time compensation (next 4 bits)
 - Din threshold set (next bit)
 - Dout level set (next bit)
 - Iout response time (bottom bit)
Returns a 32 byte slice of the EEPROM contents.  This command requires a 16-bit data offset parameter as part of the query.
Refer to New Direct II Flowchart, reset to bootloader mode is needed.
Return 48bits UID.
Reference to Short List MT Overview.
Refer to Direct II Upload Protocol Spec.
Refer to Direct II Upload Protocol Spec.
Default values: FF FF FF FF

Valid range : 0x00 - 0xff
First byte for RED channel, second byte for GREEN channel, third byte for BLUE channel, the last byte for WHITE channel.

The query should be combined with data array (PDL = 1) :
00: Global power scale.
01: RED channel power scale.
02: GREEN channel power scale.
03: BLUE channel power scale.
04: WHITE channel power scale.

Returns power scale value in HEX format. First byte for LED channel, the second byte for power scaler.
The scaler is an 8 bit value for each channel, which is used to redece the output of one or more channels.
The actual LED channel output is scaled according to this equation: actual output = input * scaler / 255.
First byte for LED channel, the second byte for power scaler.
Support broadcast on passthrough devices
Support broadcast on passthrough devices
Support broadcast on passthrough devices

Purpose: Set PDS bootloader target SN list
Description:
Sets list of device serial numbers to bootload.  
Packet structure is as follows:
- Packet sequence (1 byte)
- Serial number count (1 byte)
- Serial number list (packed, no delimiters, big endian) (variable length)
NACK responses are as follows:
- 0x0004: Device not in bootloader mode
- 0x0006: PDS serial number list size <1 or >255, or packet SN count <1 or >38
- 0x0009: Serial number in list not known to PDS, or SFT versions do not match
The ACK response contains the total number of serial numbers in the list

Includes:
- Image size in bytes (8 bytes)
- Image CRC (8 bytes) [CRC-16 CCITT is the algorithm used]
- Image version (8 bytes)
- SFT number (8 bytes)
NACK responses are as follows:
- 0x0001: payload size is not 4 bytes
- 0x0004: device not in bootloader mode
- 0x0006: SFT mismatch, image too large, or other problem with the payload
ACK responses contain the size of the flash block in bytes (2 bytes)

Sets a single flash block fragment of the boot image.  Format is as follows:
- Packet sequence number (2 bytes)
- Payload byte count (1 byte)
- Payload (variable up to 228 bytes)
ACK response format is as follows
- Packet sequenct number (2 bytes)
- Hold time until next packet (milliseconds) (4 bytes)
NACK responses are as follows:
- 0x0001: CRC failure
- 0x0002: Write failure
- 0x0004: Device not ready to receive image data
- 0x0006: Packet out of sequence, SFT mismatch, or data size incorrect

Instructs PDS to begin the bootloading process.  For PDS updates, this validates the image and sets the boot target.  For subdevice updates, this validates the image and begins bootloading the subdevices in the target list.
NACK responses are as follows:
- 0x0002: Failed to initiate bootloading process

Returns the status of the current bootloading operation.  Response format is as follows:
- Serial nmber list size (1 byte)
- Current serial number list index (1 byte)
- Serial number (8 byte)
- Status code for current serial number (1 byte):
-- 0x00: Not done
-- 0x01: In progress
-- 0x02: Done
-- 0x03: CRC mismatch
-- 0x04: Failed Flash
-- 0x05: SFT mismatch
-- 0x06: UU file header parse error
-- 0x07: Authenticate error
-- 0x08: Decryption error
-- 0x09 – 0xFF: reserved
Places PDS into bootloader mode and returns encryption parameters.  SET commands which lack the proper magic value are responded with NACK:NR_UNKNOWN_PID

Aborts the bootload process.  ACK responses contain a single byte status code as follows:
- 0x00: Abort unsuccessful
- 0x01: Abort will occur after current subdevice completes
- 0x02: Abort successful
